When it comes to sex, we are - in theory - living
in wildly liberated times.

10.text:
So you’d think it would easy to feel at
ease owning up to certain sorts of sexual desires.

15.text:
But for most of us, the world doesn’t actually
feel that generous about fetishes.

21.text:
It’s very tricky to talk about many of the
things that turn us on - especially with our partners.

26.text:
Our fetishes can seem deeply weird, perverse
or politically incorrect.

31.text:
So we stay quiet.
And it is not only the reactions of others

35.text:
which cause us anxiety. We might at times
ourselves worry there’s something a bit wrong with us.

40.text:
To get more confident, we should get philosophical
about sex and ask: what do our fetishes  really mean?

46.text: Why do we even have them?

48.text:
The good news is that the things that turn
us on are in fact really very logical and

53.text: hardly ever simply odd or twisted.

55.text:
Here is how it works:
Every fetish or sexual obsession is really

59.text:
an imagined erotic solution to a real world
anxiety.

64.text:
Let’s look at some very common turn ons
through this theory:

70.text: People in uniforms are for many of us a major turn on, especially doctors, nurses, firemen and pilots.

77.text: Tellingly, erotic websites are full of uniforms

83.text:
As so often with turn-ons, uniforms are exciting
because there is an underlying anxiety around them.

88.text:
How many times we’re belittled by people
in uniform: ignored by a busy doctor,

93.text: made to feel like lowly fools by the heroic fireman, intimidated by the pilot…

98.text:
Authority is frequently hostile to us and
frustrates our desires.

102.text:
But in sex, we can reverse this situation.
Here uniforms can be invited into our games.

108.text:
The uniform still stands for authority.
But now authority has moved to our side, paying

113.text: us exactly the right kind of attention.

116.text:
The pilot, far from being impassively at the
controls, is thrilled to be here with us,

121.text:
she is no longer a stern-faced controller
of the Airbus A380, but our collaborator and friend.

127.text:
The busy sensible doctor is no longer just
stern and responsible, only interested in

131.text:
blood sugar levels and kidney functions: he
wants us to have fun.

136.text:
A real world ideal is being sketched in sex:
we’re being invited to imagine what authority

140.text:
might like if it helped rather than hindered
us, reassured rather than intimidated us.

146.text:
Sex is hinting at a utopia where strength,
organisation, neatness and order would be

151.text:
there to make us feel more at ease, more relaxed
and truer to ourselves.

158.text:
We are taught from a young age that we must
become independent. We live in an individualistic

163.text:
culture that constantly vilifies dependence
and pushes us towards an ideal of solitary maturity.

169.text:
But some of us are excited by something very
different: the idea of submission, of being

174.text:
totally passive, perhaps becoming someone’s
slave, surrendering all autonomy and just

180.text:
letting another person do everything and anything
to us.

184.text:
Being a ‘slave’ means that someone else
will know exactly what we should do, will

187.text:
take full responsibility, will take choice
away from us.

191.text:
This is curiously nice, because we’re not
surrendering to any old person, we’re surrendering

196.text:
to someone who is good and kind and interested
in our pleasure. The delight we take in surrender

202.text:
reveals how hard it is always to have to be
in control - how much we long for someone

206.text:
else to take charge fully sometimes, as a
relief from the pressures of daily life.

211.text:
In the real world so many crucial tasks actually
depend on one’s capacity not to be daunted

217.text:
by suffering. Taking on the masochistic role
rehearses - in erotic play - a fundamental

223.text:
idea, that of being good at suffering, of
being willing and able (and even at time eager)

229.text:
to “take it”: to be strong because one
has invited someone to call one a stupid bastard or a bitch.

236.text:
It’s a common feature of all sexual fantasies
that they do not – of course – genuinely

240.text:
solve the problems from which they draw their
excitement. But we shouldn’t worry if the

244.text:
fantasy fails to solve the problem in reality.
What we’re looking for here is simply a

248.text:
way of explaining and sympathising with the
desire and the erotic relief.

254.text:
We’re not generally allowed to be very bossy
with anyone. In our hearts, we might like

258.text:
to be very demanding and insistent. We might
like to enforce absolute obedience on all

263.text:
those who defy us. But we know how bad it
is to be too strict and tyrannical. We have

268.text: to go gently - all the time.

270.text:
But in a sexual game, our will to dominate
can be let loose. Someone puts themselves

274.text:
in our hands and asks that we do with them
as we please. What a deep honour!

279.text:
They allow us to shout, bully and order us around - as
we otherwise never dare to.

284.text:
And now the commands are met only with delight.
You can be as strong, harsh and insistent

289.text:
as you like, safe in the knowledge that the
other person is going to be just fine.

295.text:
Why can it be such a turn on to do it outside?
In a park, an elevator, or the toilets behind the party...

302.text:
Again, it’s to do with healing a wound from
daily life.

305.text:
Normally, we sense that we have to be guarded,
on our best behaviour: out there in the elevators,

310.text:
public plazas, shopping centres, garage forecourts
of the world. Even nature is seen as quite

315.text:
hostile – a cold, dangerous place where
enemies may set upon us.

320.text:
But in the sex games we play outside, we can
prove that the public realm is not as threatening

324.text:
as we had supposed. We can behave as we’d
like. Show our desires, and survive. And if

330.text:
other people disapprove, that can’t stop
us, we’re strong enough to disregard them.

334.text:
Public sex civilises the wilderness and the
lonely formal places of the city.

339.text: It lets us feel more at home in the world.

342.text:
One can analyse almost any so-called fetish
and find similar structures: an anxiety and

347.text:
a corresponding solution, to which an erotic
charge has become connected.

350.text:
Looked at like this, sexual scenarios can
be explained to ourselves – and, crucially

355.text:
to other people in our lives – in fairly
rational, sensible terms.

359.text:
Ee can explain how our fear
of being responsible became oppressive, and

362.text:
therefore why we enjoy being put in a dog
collar. Or why we were afraid of authority,

367.text:
and therefore what fun it is to be examined
by a doctor in bed.

371.text:
By talking like this, we can hope that sexual
tastes will become less a little shameful

375.text:
and a little less threatening – and our
erotic games in their own way, a lot more
